intro: Poranthera corymbosa var. linearoides, commonly known as the narrowleaf sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Plantaginaceae family and is characterized by its slender, linear leaves and clusters of small, pink to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and thrives in full sun, making it well adapted to arid environments. Its flowering period occurs in the spring and early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The species is often used in xeriscaping due to its drought tolerance and ornamental value.
